intro: Eriogonum montanum, commonly known as mountain buckwheat, is a flowering plant native to the western United States. It is a member of the Polygonaceae family and is characterized by its upright growth habit and clusters of small, white to pinkish flowers. The plant typically grows in dry, rocky habitats such as slopes and meadows, thriving in full sun. Its leaves are usually lance-shaped and covered in fine hairs, and it produces edible seeds that are consumed by various wildlife species. Eriogonum montanum plays an important ecological role in stabilizing soil and providing food for pollinators.
